resource.name: General Building Permits
resource.description:
List of issued building permits from the City of Edmonton - Urban Planning & Economy Department for the public to do construction or maintenance on a structure located in the City. Note - All records start from January 1, 2009.
Please note : the decision was made to not release applicant information on this dataset as it was seen as a potential privacy issue. For instance, if a high profile member of the public were to apply for a permit, their name (and consequently address) would show up on this table and become easily searchable by the public.  We viewed this as a potential issue and decided to publish the dataset without applicant information.

resource.name: City of Edmonton - Business Licences
resource.description:
List of establishments that have a valid business licence to operate in the City of Edmonton.

On August 2, 2023, a manual dataset update was executed to bring the data closer to real-time while waiting for the completion of the implementation of the new business licence bylaw and the restoration of the automated feed. 

The regular data refresh is expected to resume in 2024

City Council has approved a new Business Licence Bylaw effective January 17, 2022. To support this new bylaw, our data systems are undergoing a series of major enhancements. For more information about the new Business Licence Bylaw, visit https://www.edmonton.ca/businesslicencebylawrenewal.

resource.name: 24 Hour Rainfall Totals and Storm Severity Ratings
resource.description:
Rainfall is measured to assess storms and their effects on flooding and sewer performance and design.

Rainfall location color icons indicate rainfall totals and maximum storm rating during the past 24 hours. Data is sent once 2mm is accumulated in each gauge, so timing will vary.

Website is updated every 15 minutes. Higher storm ratings and rainfall totals may have occurred if a storm lasts more than 24h. Storm ratings and rainfall are based on data at the gauge location only - nearby areas may experience differing conditions due to variability of rainstorms.

Rainfall is measured between May and October; snowfall is not measured.

Unique identifier for a rain gauge.

Rolling 24-hour rainfall total, in millimetres. Values will hold steady until the next data point restarts the calculations, until the following 23:59:59 at the latest (gauge sends a zero data point each day at 23:59:59 so there is always recent data if not raining).
Time when rain fall data is collected.

Unique identifier for the Storm Rating Description. 
Maximum Rating over past 24 hours. Values will hold steady until the next data point restarts the calculations, until the following 23:59:59 at the latest. Calculation based on rainfall total and intensity, land characteristics in the area (e.g.-amount of pavement), and an index for wetness of the ground.
The rainfall amount range measured in millimetres, used for the map legend.
Date when rain gauge rain fall data is collected

resource.name: January 2021 Mixed Topic - Member Check-in - Edmonton Insight Community
resource.description:
This was one single topic among many, from the January 2021 Mixed Topic survey. To view the survey questions, click the following link:

https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/c/a/6JaKdDpmVL11hwGrkft80a?t=1

Open from January 12-19, 2021.

At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 12,423 Insight Community Members. 3016 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 24.27%. A total of 3027 respondents completed the survey: 2016 Insight Community Members, 6 from the call to action button on our webpage, and 5 using the anonymous link on Edmonton.ca/Surveys which will have no demographic info.

resource.name: Driver Feedback Sign - DFS055
resource.description:
Driver Feedback Sign DFS055

Latitude: 53.5923
Longitude: -113.47047

The City has a number of Driver Feedback Signs (DFS) installed around the city. These units collect data as traffic approaches them and in some cases may display a message or a speed that is being detected. Also, these units are radar based and can only track one vehicle at a time (strongest signal).

Due to the number of DFS installations combined with the volume of data collected, each DFS has its own dataset.

Details of how the data is collected by the DFS are as follows:
- Data is accumulated and reported in 15 minute intervals
- Vehicle speeds are captured/reported in speed intervals (bins)
- Speed range/interval for the bins are determined by parameters/settings set for the DFS (Minimum/Maximum Speed Detection Setting)
- Two speed values are recorded for every vehicle - a Highest Speed Detected and a Slowest Speed Detected (explaining why there are two vehicle counts)
- The bins go from Bin 1 to Bin 10. Bin 1 can also be referred to a LO BIN and Bin 10 can also be referred to as HIGH BIN.

Things to note:

DFS devices are not to be used as or confused with traffic counters, as they are not.
DFS devices have a minimum detectable speed of approximately 6 km/hr.
DFS devices have a maximum (theoretical) detectable speed of approximately 225 km/hr.
DFS devices are programmable with different parameters that can also follow a timed schedule.
columns_name: Vehicle Count at Slowest Speed Detected
Vehicle Count at Highest Speed Detected
columns_description: The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected slowest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

The slowest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel equal to or faster than this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH.

A value between 1 and 10, representing the data bin for which the vehicle count and the speed range is applicable.  Bin 1 records the number of vehicles that were detected to travel in the slowest speed range and Bin 10 would be for the fastest speed range.
The Speed Limit setting for the DFS unit.  Note: This may not be the enforceable speed for the roadway.

The number of vehicles that were successfully detected and recorded within the specified parameters.  This Vehicle Count is not and should not be correlated to a traffic volume count within the 15 minute interval.
The fastest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
System generated ID to eliminate the possibility of duplicate data.

The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected fastest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

The Timestamp of when the data was recorded.  The time interval between recordings is 15 minutes.  Note: It is possible to not have a specific recording of data at a specific Timestamp.  This can occur for a number of reasons; however, the data values are still for the 15 minute interval.

The fastest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel less than or equal to this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.
The lowest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
The direction of travel of vehicles that are being detected by the DFS unit.

A flag value that indicates the following: 0 - if the both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are below the Speed Limit 1 - if the Speed Limit is between the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin 2 - if the value of both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are greater than the Speed Limit
A unique ID assigned to the location for proper/accurate identification.
A brief / abbreviated description of the location where the DFS unit is located.

A calculated value based on (Maximum Speed Detection Setting and Minimum Speed Detection Setting).   NOTE: - For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH. - For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.
The Speed Unit of Measure.  Note: The usual setting is KPH but could also be MPH.

domain_metadata.value: To share with the public the collection of speed data at the various locations throughout Edmonton.

resource.name: Driver Feedback Sign - DFS072
resource.description:
Driver Feedback Sign DFS072

Latitude: 53.5412
Longitude: -113.45524

The City has a number of Driver Feedback Signs (DFS) installed around the city. These units collect data as traffic approaches them and in some cases may display a message or a speed that is being detected. Also, these units are radar based and can only track one vehicle at a time (strongest signal).

Due to the number of DFS installations combined with the volume of data collected, each DFS has its own dataset.

Details of how the data is collected by the DFS are as follows:
- Data is accumulated and reported in 15 minute intervals
- Vehicle speeds are captured/reported in speed intervals (bins)
- Speed range/interval for the bins are determined by parameters/settings set for the DFS (Minimum/Maximum Speed Detection Setting)
- Two speed values are recorded for every vehicle - a Highest Speed Detected and a Slowest Speed Detected (explaining why there are two vehicle counts)
- The bins go from Bin 1 to Bin 10. Bin 1 can also be referred to a LO BIN and Bin 10 can also be referred to as HIGH BIN.

Things to note:

DFS devices are not to be used as or confused with traffic counters, as they are not.
DFS devices have a minimum detectable speed of approximately 6 km/hr.
DFS devices have a maximum (theoretical) detectable speed of approximately 225 km/hr.
DFS devices are programmable with different parameters that can also follow a timed schedule.
columns_name: Vehicle Count at Slowest Speed Detected
Vehicle Count at Highest Speed Detected
columns_description: The fastest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel less than or equal to this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.

The Timestamp of when the data was recorded.  The time interval between recordings is 15 minutes.  Note: It is possible to not have a specific recording of data at a specific Timestamp.  This can occur for a number of reasons; however, the data values are still for the 15 minute interval.
The lowest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
The Speed Limit setting for the DFS unit.  Note: This may not be the enforceable speed for the roadway.

The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected slowest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

A flag value that indicates the following: 0 - if the both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are below the Speed Limit 1 - if the Speed Limit is between the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin 2 - if the value of both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are greater than the Speed Limit

The slowest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel equal to or faster than this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH.
System generated ID to eliminate the possibility of duplicate data.

The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected fastest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

The number of vehicles that were successfully detected and recorded within the specified parameters.  This Vehicle Count is not and should not be correlated to a traffic volume count within the 15 minute interval.
A brief / abbreviated description of the location where the DFS unit is located.
The direction of travel of vehicles that are being detected by the DFS unit.
A unique ID assigned to the location for proper/accurate identification.

A value between 1 and 10, representing the data bin for which the vehicle count and the speed range is applicable.  Bin 1 records the number of vehicles that were detected to travel in the slowest speed range and Bin 10 would be for the fastest speed range.
The fastest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
The Speed Unit of Measure.  Note: The usual setting is KPH but could also be MPH.

A calculated value based on (Maximum Speed Detection Setting and Minimum Speed Detection Setting).   NOTE: - For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH. - For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.

domain_metadata.value: To share with the public the collection of speed data at the various locations throughout Edmonton.

resource.name: Revenue Vehicle Hours per Capita
resource.description: Measures number of hours buses and LRT are scheduled to travel while in revenue service on a per capita basis.
columns_description: Number of hours buses and LRT are scheduled to travel while in revenue service on a per capita basis.
Population relating to the calendar year.
Number of hours that buses and LRT cars are scheduled to travel while in revenue service per year. This excludes deadhead and garage in/out hours.
Calendar year the data represents.

resource.name: Historical: COVID-19 in Alberta: People tested for COVID-19 in Alberta by age group and gender
resource.description:
Note: Date last updated is 2022-03-17, dataset is no longer provided.

From https://www.alberta.ca/covid-19-alberta-data.aspx; updated 2023-08-29 15:15 with data as of end of day 2023-07-24.
columns_description: Cumulative count of males tested as of the specified date.
Cumulative count of people of all sexes tested as of the specified date.
The date on which the data was made available by AHS.
Cumulative count of people of unknown sex tested as of the specified date.
Cumulative count of females tested as of the specified date.
Age group.

resource.name: Bylaw Complaint Details
resource.description: Total number of citizen complaint driven or officer initiated Bylaw investigations starting Jan 1, 2011 to present day.
columns_name: Edmonton Public School Board (EPSB) Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
City of Edmonton - Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
Edmonton Catholic School District Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
columns_description: The longitude value of the closest roadway intersection of where the Bylaw complaint came from.
The latitude value of the closest roadway intersection of where the Bylaw complaint came from.
The name of the Street on which the Bylaw complaint originated from.
The Neighbourhood in which the Bylaw complaint originated in.
General classification/description of complaint made according to a specific by-law.
The specific date as to when the Bylaw Complaint was created in the system.  This date does not directly reflect the date of when the Bylaw Complaint took place.
A unique ID assigned to the Neighbourhood in which the Bylaw complaint originated in.
A unique ID to identify a particular complaint.  A complaint may involve one or more properties.
A Yes/No field that indicates if the complaint was cannabis related.
The latitude/longitude combination of the closest roadway intersection of where the Bylaw complaint came from.  This is used for mapping purposes.
The combination of the numeric 2 digit month combined with the 3 letter abbreviation representing the month in which the Bylaw complaint ticket was created.
The numeric year representing the year in which the Bylaw Complaint ticket was created.
The status for the specific Complaint.  Options are: New, Investigation Scheduled, Inspection Conducted, and Completed
The number of instances/complaints that were entered for the particular Bylaw entry into the system.
A categorization of the various Types of Complaints to make it easier to filter the data by.
A Yes (Y) or No (N) value that identifies if the complaint was initiated by a Bylaw Officer.  Y means it was initiated by a Bylaw Officer and N means it was initiated by a Citizen.

domain_metadata.value: To provide an up to date daily and historical bylaw complaint details of investigations.

resource.name: Fraud Awareness - Edmonton Insight Community
resource.description:
This was one single topic among a couple from the March 2019 Mixed Topic survey. To view the survey questions, click on the following link:

https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/c/a/6ASXWfhoFPzA5wspHQtHNp?t=1

Open from March 12 - 19, 2019. 

At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 10,136 Insight Community Members. 2,316 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 23%. A total of 2,329 respondents completed the survey: 2,316 Insight Community Members and 6 from the call to action button on our webpage and 7 using the anonymous link(s) on edmonton.ca/surveys which will have no demographic information.

Column definitions can be found as an attachment to this dataset (under the About option, in the Attachment section).
columns_name: Qposter2_Seeing a sign like this would deter me from using an bitcoin ATM.
Qposter2_This information on this sign provides useful information regarding bitcoin fraud.
Qposter2_The information on this sign is easy to understand.
Qposter2_I know where to go for more information regarding bitcoin.

domain_metadata.value: To share with the public results of monthly survey results for a specific topic.

resource.name: Edmonton Council Membership History
resource.description:
This dataset provides the list of elected Edmonton Council members for each election starting from 1892.

The information within is derived from publicly accessible sources, often historical in nature. While every effort was made to ensure accuracy, some discrepancies may exist. Questions and requests for clarification can be sent to the elections office by clicking on the “contact dataset owner” button.
columns_description: date on which the election was held
full name of council member
first name of council member
elected term refers to the full term length for that position in a general election
office position elected
sex of council member (male or female)
last name of council member
notes associated with the elected term length

resource.name: Driver Feedback Sign - DFS141
resource.description:
Driver Feedback Sign DFS141

Latitude: 53.55089
Longitude: -113.52938

The City has a number of Driver Feedback Signs (DFS) installed around the city. These units collect data as traffic approaches them and in some cases may display a message or a speed that is being detected. Also, these units are radar based and can only track one vehicle at a time (strongest signal).

Due to the number of DFS installations combined with the volume of data collected, each DFS has its own dataset.

Details of how the data is collected by the DFS are as follows:
- Data is accumulated and reported in 15 minute intervals
- Vehicle speeds are captured/reported in speed intervals (bins)
- Speed range/interval for the bins are determined by parameters/settings set for the DFS (Minimum/Maximum Speed Detection Setting)
- Two speed values are recorded for every vehicle - a Highest Speed Detected and a Slowest Speed Detected (explaining why there are two vehicle counts)
- The bins go from Bin 1 to Bin 10. Bin 1 can also be referred to a LO BIN and Bin 10 can also be referred to as HIGH BIN.

Things to note:

DFS devices are not to be used as or confused with traffic counters, as they are not.
DFS devices have a minimum detectable speed of approximately 6 km/hr.
DFS devices have a maximum (theoretical) detectable speed of approximately 225 km/hr.
DFS devices are programmable with different parameters that can also follow a timed schedule.
columns_name: Vehicle Count at Highest Speed Detected
Vehicle Count at Slowest Speed Detected
columns_description: The fastest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel less than or equal to this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.

The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected fastest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

A flag value that indicates the following: 0 - if the both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are below the Speed Limit 1 - if the Speed Limit is between the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin 2 - if the value of both the Minimum Speed and Maximum Speed for the Bin are greater than the Speed Limit

A calculated value based on (Maximum Speed Detection Setting and Minimum Speed Detection Setting).   NOTE: - For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH. - For Bin 10, the maximum detectable speed is approximately 225 KPH.

The Timestamp of when the data was recorded.  The time interval between recordings is 15 minutes.  Note: It is possible to not have a specific recording of data at a specific Timestamp.  This can occur for a number of reasons; however, the data values are still for the 15 minute interval.
System generated ID to eliminate the possibility of duplicate data.

The number of vehicles that were successfully detected and recorded within the specified parameters.  This Vehicle Count is not and should not be correlated to a traffic volume count within the 15 minute interval.

The number of vehicles counted in the 15 minute time interval where the detected slowest speed of the vehicle was equal to or greater than the Minimum Speed for the Bin and is less than or equal to the Maximum Speed for the Bin.

A value between 1 and 10, representing the data bin for which the vehicle count and the speed range is applicable.  Bin 1 records the number of vehicles that were detected to travel in the slowest speed range and Bin 10 would be for the fastest speed range.
A unique ID assigned to the location for proper/accurate identification.
The Speed Unit of Measure.  Note: The usual setting is KPH but could also be MPH.
A brief / abbreviated description of the location where the DFS unit is located.
The Speed Limit setting for the DFS unit.  Note: This may not be the enforceable speed for the roadway.

The slowest detected speed travelled that corresponds to the Bin Number.  Vehicles can travel equal to or faster than this speed for it to be recorded for the Bin.  NOTE: For Bin 1, the minimum detectable speed is approximately 6 KPH.
The fastest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
The lowest speed setting for the DFS Unit used to determine the speed ranges for each Bin.
The direction of travel of vehicles that are being detected by the DFS unit.

resource.name: Litter Audit - Site Results
resource.description: Audit results for each year.  Each Audit Site is categorized into Large Litter Items and Small Litter Items.  Audit years available are from 2009 to 2016.  For Audit Site details, please refer to data set: Litter Audit - Site List
columns_name: City of Edmonton - Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
Edmonton Catholic School District Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
Edmonton Public School Board (EPSB) Ward Boundaries (effective at 12:00 AM on Oct 16, 2017)
Edmonton Catholic School District Ward Boundaries
Edmonton Public School Board Ward Boundaries
columns_description: The count of large litter items found at the site in the given audit year.  Definition of a large litter item is: any item that is 25.8 square centimeters or larger
The year that the audit data was collected.
A more specific description of the location of the trash audit site.  The description may even be a general area (from this point to this point).
Latitude,Longitude - geolocation where the audit took place.
The latitude value for the trash audit site (it would be the latitude value of the centre point of the area if the site covers an area).
A brief description of the approximate location of the trash audit site.
A system assigned sequential number given to the physical location where a trash audit takes place each year.
The longitude value for the trash audit site (it would be the latitude value of the centre point of the area if the site covers an area).
The count of small litter items found at the site in the given audit year.  Definition of a small litter item is: that is less than 25.8 square centimeters

resource.name: 2015 Edmonton Public School Board By-Election - Results Detail (by Voting Station)
resource.description: Official Results from the 2015 Edmonton School Board By-Election (Ward G). Results are displayed for each Candidate, by Race and by Voting Station.
columns_description: Votes received by candidate (under votes are ballots counted with no selection for this race; Over votes are ballots counted with more than the allowable number of selections in a race - no votes are assigned to a candidate.
Type of voting station; regular is election day voting station and advance is for the advance voting stations
Unique identifier for election race.
Candidate first name
Name of ward
Name of race
Description of voting station
A candidate is acclaimed if there is only one nomination for that race.
Estimated number of eligible voters reporting to this voting station based on the Municipal Census (shown for Regular Voting Stations only).
Name of the facility where the voting station was held (Advance voting stations will have a blank value as it is a combination of many facilities)
Candidate last name

resource.name: E-Scooter Operational Zones
resource.description:
E-Scooter operational zones for Edmonton, as provided by the E-Scooter vendors.

Please note that the operational zone boundary most recently provided by a particular vendor might not necessarily be the current operational zone when you view this dataset; there may be a delay in obtaining data to reflect changes to boundaries during the year, or operations may have ceased for the winter with the most recently-provided boundary still being that associated with the previous summer. Please check with the vendors themselves for verified current operational boundaries.
columns_description: The date on which the zone became effective.

Indicates whether the effective-dated row is "current", i.e. the greatest effective date value that is less than or equal to the date on which the dataset was last updated. To facilitate easier filtering. NB: This does not necessarily mean that the zone is actually currently active; the vendor may have ceased operations for the winter for example.

These words are found in applicable legislation, the Edmonton Zoning Bylaw and in the current notification letters. In your opinion what word is most appropriate to use in describing a shift away from the standard regulations? || vary - variance to the regulation\relax - relaxation of the regulation\reduce - reduction to the regulation\Other\None of these

resource.name: Mosquito Application by Backpack (2020)
resource.description:
This dataset represents the GPS coordinates and other relevant information of where backpack application/treatment took place for mosquitoes for 2020.

A brief description of how it works:

GPS coordinates are obtained from a cell phone, which is connected to an Arduino. A stretch sensor connected to the Arduino is used to detect where pesticide is sprayed.

Things to consider when working with this dataset:

The setup has been tested for accuracy but it is possible for equipment to report incorrect data. Values may be changed due to correction or re-calibration.  Values may also be incorrect due to malfunctioning equipment that went undetected for a period of time.
columns_description: GPS Longitude in DD.dddddddd
GPS Latitude in DD.dddddddd
Decimal degrees; Direction of travel with respect to true North
The date and time of when the GPS and related data was recorded.
A unique row identifier used to ensure no duplicate records are created.
Speed in kilometers per hour
System Serial Number
The accuracy of the latitude/longitude recording, measured in metres.

domain_metadata.value: To share with the public where applying treatment for mosquitoes took place.

resource.name: School Bus Parking In Residential Areas - Edmonton Insight Community
resource.description:
This was one single topic among many, from the February 2018 Mixed Topic survey. To view the survey questions, click on the following link:

https://www.edmontoninsightcommunity.ca/c/a/5tKHEJ44EOxCU3WV2dl88H?t=1

Open from February 13 - 20, 2018. 

At the time the survey was launched survey invitations were sent to 7,131 Insight Community Members. 2,024 members completed the survey which represents a completion rate of 28%. A total of 2,071 respondents completed the survey: 2,024 Insight Community Members and 7 from the call to action button on our webpage and 40 using the anonymous link(s) on edmonton.ca/surveys which will have no demographic information.

Column definitions can be found as an attachment to this dataset (under the About option, in the Attachment section).
columns_name: Q3_BusParking_I don’t have any concerns about school busses parking in residential areas during the day
Q3_BusParking_Lack of places to park on the street
Q3_BusParking_Negative local environmental impacts like noise and fumes

domain_tags: school bus parking in residential areas

domain_metadata.value: To share with the public results of monthly survey results for a specific topic.
